{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3559051,"name":"","username":"potatoez0319","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/77aa72/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T07:31:37.134Z","cooked":"

Hi!

I have a romi robot (Pololu - Romi Robot Kit for FIRST - Red) and I would like it to consistently and accurately turn 90 degrees. I want the romi to perform 20 consecutive 90 degree turns accurately. I was wondering what the best way to do that would be.

I know about gyroscopes and PID. I have an algorithm where I read the degrees turned with the gyroscope and turn the robot until the turned angle is equal to 90 degrees. However, with this algorithm, the turns get less accurate over time (the romi turns >90 degrees after only about 4 turns). Are there better algorithms out there so that the robot can do this task?

Thank you!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T07:31:37.134Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":41,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":237.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495867,"topic_slug":"whats-the-best-way-to-get-a-two-wheeled-robot-to-turn-exactly-90-degrees-consistenly","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.pololu.com/product/4022","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Pololu - Romi Robot Kit for FIRST - Red","clicks":21}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73902,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/whats-the-best-way-to-get-a-two-wheeled-robot-to-turn-exactly-90-degrees-consistenly/495867/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3559053,"name":"Joey Tidrow","username":"Arrowmag","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arrowmag/{size}/233870_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T07:51:45.431Z","cooked":"

It looks like there are encoders on the wheel motors. I would recommend using those in combination with the gryoscope and a PID controller. There are more complex motion control algorithms out there but I think the encoders should do the trick.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-17T07:51:45.431Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":172,"readers_count":171,"score":44.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495867,"topic_slug":"whats-the-best-way-to-get-a-two-wheeled-robot-to-turn-exactly-90-degrees-consistenly","display_username":"Joey Tidrow","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59796,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1646M 2851A "},"post_url":"/t/whats-the-best-way-to-get-a-two-wheeled-robot-to-turn-exactly-90-degrees-consistenly/495867/2","custom_user_title":"1646M 2851A ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3559131,"name":"Joe Ross","username":"Joe_Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T12:42:47.742Z","cooked":"

What do you do when the gyro reads 90 degrees? Do you stop the motors? How do you make sure that any delay from reading the gyro to stopping the motors doesn’t keep the robot from going farther then 90 degrees?

How do you do the second turn? Do you reset the gyro and go to 90? Do you go to 180? Do you go to the current gyro position + 90? Think about how errors can accumulate over multiple runs.

When the turns get less accurate, have you looked at the gyro angle to see if the problem is the gyro reading, or the robot going to the correct gyro reading?

Thanks for your reply! I’ll try that.

Thanks for your reply!

I have a braking algorithm to stop the robot (makes the wheels turn in the opposite direction at max speed for 10 milliseconds and then stop the wheels).

I think the time between calling the stop and the actual stop is minimal? I made the robot turn really slow and the error is still there.

I reset the gyro after every turn. I think the error accumulating over time is the issue (or maybe the gyro isn’t resetting correctly?)

I’m pretty sure the robot goes to the correct gyro reading.

Would you like to see my code for more clarification? Thank you so much.
